thread.title: UPDATE 3-Fiat Chrysler, U.S. union UAW reach tentative agreement
thread.title_full: UPDATE 3-Fiat Chrysler, U.S. union UAW reach tentative agreement | Reuters

author: Reuters
title: UPDATE 3-Fiat Chrysler, U.S. union UAW reach tentative agreement
text:
* UAW said it would terminate current contract at midnight
* Tentative contract was rejected by union members last week
* Talks went down to the deadline (Updates with tentative agreement details)
By Bernie Woodall
DETROIT, Oct 8 (Reuters) - Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV and the United Auto Workers said on Thursday they had reached a new tentative four-year labor agreement that averted a threatened strike of the automaker's U.S. operations.
The agreement must be ratified by a vote of Fiat Chrysler's 40,000 union workers in the United States. A previous proposed contract was rejected by rank and file UAW workers at Fiat Chrysler in voting late last month.
The UAW Chrysler Council will meet in Detroit at 11 am/1600 GMT on Friday to discuss the agreement and vote on it, the union said.
The UAW had previously told the company that it would terminate the current labor contract if a new four-year contract deal was not reached by 11:59 pm EDT on Wednesday/0359 GMT on Thursday.
The company confirmed it had reached a tentative agreement but said it could not disclose details ahead of the UAW membership vote.
A union spokesman gave no details of the talks including whether the company was willing to sweeten the deal it offered the UAW that was approved Sept. 18 by the union leaders but rejected last week by 65 percent of its rank-and-file Fiat Chrysler membership.
Workers have said they turned down the previous contract because many wanted a two-tier wage and benefit system eliminated. Short of that, they sought a cap on that lower-paid second tier at 25 percent of the total union workforce. Many workers also wish to undo some of the concessions they have given since 2007 to keep the company competitive.
If this agreement is ratified, the UAW will try to use the pact as a template for negotiations with the U.S. operations of General Motors Co and Ford Motor Co. (Additional reporting by Agnieszka Flak in Milan; Editing by Ken Wills )
